chl.title: Introduction
chl.p: This document describes procedures for how to install the Home Subscriber Server (HSS) on the Ericsson Telecom Server (TSP). Classic and HSS Front End deployment configurations and also stand-alone and redundant configurations are covered here.
HSS plugin validator software installation is not covered in this document.

list.p: This document covers the following topics:

chl.title: Prerequisites
chl.p: This section describes the prerequisites which must be fulfilled before the HSS can be installed.

list.p: The user must have the following:

list-item.p: Direct access to the TSP Generic Equipment Magazine (GEM) cabinet.
Basic system administrator level knowledge of the TSP and Linux.
Knowledge on how to edit in a UNIX™/Linux™ environment text editor such as vi, emacs, or textedit.
Knowledge on how to connect to, and log on to, the IO of a cabinet.

list.p: The following hardware and software is required:

list-item.p: NSP6.1 hardware must be used for HSS installation
For more information about TSP installation details, see the following document:
TSP Runtime Maiden Installation for NSP 6.1, .

During the TSP installation process several options are presented, use 64-bit as target type to be installed. Regarding "File separation by zone" option, select the default value NO for standalone. In case of using NetRed and POTs of FTU in the NetShared POT list, use YES option

To install Monolithic Geographical Redundancy, two TSP nodes are required. Both nodes should have the same hardware and TSP software version (with Geographical Redundancy template installed). One of them must use the zone 1 templates and the other node must use the zone 2 templates provided by the TSP release. In case connection towards an HLR is needed, notice that it is recommended to use a different Signaling Point Code for the configuration of SS7 in each HSS node. For more information, refer to SS7 configuration use Configuring SS7 Signaling Network, M3, IETF, .
During the SS7 installation process, several options are presented; select MAP&INAP Standard. Refer to Configuring SS7, INAP, , and Configuring SS7, MAP, .
OSPF is basically used for supervision of links and routers. To modify the right timers to be used for the HSS/SLF-FE, refer to HSS Reference ConfigurationHSS Reference Configuration, .
Configure the node to synchronize timekeeping with a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server.

HSS uses the VIP link functionality provided by TSP platform. In a standard configuration, several VIP configurations are mandatory. For details, refer to HSS Reference ConfigurationHSS Reference Configuration, .

Choose the proper ntd template in the initial Maiden Installation. Different ntd templates are provided with different processor profiles, depending on the number of Dicos processors available in the system. Two processors at least for each profile must be used. For recommendations regarding which profile to assign for every processor, refer to HSS Reference ConfigurationHSS Reference Configuration, .
For nodes with 2 Dicos processors in a subrack the ntd templates needed are located in io2: $TSP_DISTRIBUTION_ROOT/config/ntd/ims64/6TP.
The following Dicos profile is available: Dicos_TP_Diameter_SCTP_FE. See for further details.

For nodes with 3 or more Dicos processors in a subrack for Front End deployment in a subrack available in the system, the ntd templates needed are located in io2: $TSP_DISTRIBUTION_ROOT/config/ntd/ims64/small.
The following Dicos profiles are available: Dicos_TP_Diameter, Dicos_TP_Diameter_SCTP_FE. See for further details.
For bigger nodes, more than one subrack, the ntd templates needed are located in io2: $TSP_DISTRIBUTION_ROOT/config/ntd/ims64/
The following Dicos profiles are available: Dicos_TP_Diameter, SS7_SCTP_FE. See for recommendations regarding which profile to be assigned for every processor.
To check if SS7 configuration is needed to select the right ntd file, refer to Licensing Management in HSSLicensing Management in HSS, .

chl.title: Security Management
chl.p: In HSS, there are two different methods in order to authenticate users. The first one, also called Local Authentication, is based on the possibility of having several administrators and access groups to which these administrators can belong. The other method for authenticate users is called External Authentication, which consist that the users in the system are authenticated on an external server. For more information, refer to User Administration User GuideUser Administration User Guide, .

chl.title: Introduction to IPv6
chl.p: HSS supports IPv6 for all Diameter interfaces, over either TCP or SCTP, as well as for all MAP interfaces (over SIGTRAN). For additional information on how to configure IPv6, refer to TSP Runtime Maiden Installation for NSP 6.1, and to configure Diameter interfaces, refer to Configuring Diameter, .

chl.title: Introduction to IPsec
chl.p: HSS supports IPsec to provide security services to the IP layer. For additional information on how to configure IPsec, refer to Security Management User Guide, . IPsec is enabled through a license, Enhanced Security Support, for more information; refer to Licensing Management in HSS, .

chl.title: Own Stack Configuration
chl.p: Once the ISM/SDA software has been successfully licensed and activated, the DIA-CFG-OwnNodeConfig object created for the application has to be configured using a command-based or browser LDAP client.
These are the attributes of the DIA-CFG-OwnNodeConfig object that must be properly set for ISM/SDA:

list-item.p: hostId: Unique identifier of the node.
transportLayerType: Configure the transport layer according to the following option.
1 if the transport layer is TCP
2 if the transport layer is SCTP
3 if the first try of transport layer is SCTP and then TCP
ipAddressesList: <index: ISM/SDA IP address>, if transportLayerType is 1 or 3
sctpAddressesList: <index: ISM/SDA IP address>, if transportLayerType is 2 or 3
productName : Unique name of the product:
allowConnectFromUnknownNode: Can be set to “TRUE” in lab systems to skip neighbor node configuration.
supportedVendorsIds: List of those vendors whose AVPs are acknowledged by the Diameter node, meaning that those AVPs can be decoded/encoded by the application.
supportedVendorSpecificApps: List of Diameter application codes that the StackId supports.

bridge.p: Besides, if SDA software is licensed:

list-item.p: portNr. Port number that the application uses for communication with other nodes in the network. As different applications may use the same IP address, this value must be unique among instances of DIA-CFG-OwnNodeConfig corresponding to the different applications that make use of the Diameter stack (StackIds). The TCP port number defined by IETF for Diameter is 3868. If diameter port is configured to a different value other than 3868, the different port needs to be opened at TSP.

chl.title: Initiating Connection Neighbors
chl.p: If the allowConnectFromUnknownNode parameter is set to “FALSE” for any reason, neighbor node configuration is needed for the incoming connections. If it is set to “TRUE”, this could be skipped because dynamic connection establishment is allowed in the local node configuration.
This configuration is accomplished by creating as many DIA-CFG-NeighbourNode objects as peer nodes.
For the neighbor nodes configuration, the following information is needed:
By default just one connection is established between the neighbor nodes and ISM/SDA. If the neighbor nodes support Multiple TCP connection function, then it is recommended to add more connections. .
This configuration is accomplished by creating DIA-CFG-Conn object for the ISM/SDA neighbor node.
For the new connection, the following information is needed:

list-item.p: connId : Connection identifier, set it to “<ISM/SDA diameter stackId#neighbor hostId#connId>”.

chl.title: Non Initiating Connection Neighbors
chl.p: ISM diameter stack is responsible for initiating the connection towards SM diameter stack. If ISM needs to establish a diameter connection with SM, this configuration is accomplished creating a DIA-CFG-NeighbourNode object with the following information:

list-item.p: ipAddressList: <index 0>: SM diameter stack IP address.
portNr: SM diameter stack port number.
transportLayerType: Configure the transport layer according to the following options:
1 if the transport layer is TCP
2 if the transport layer is SCTP
3 is the first try of transport layer is SCTP and then TCP

chl.p: By default just one connection is established between the neighbor nodes and ISM/SDA. If the neighbor nodes support Multiple TCP connection function, then it is recommended to add more connections..
This configuration is accomplished by creating DIA-CFG-Conn object for the ISM/SDA neighbor node.
For the new connection, the following information is needed:

list-item.p: sctpAddressesList: <index: ISM/SDA IP address>, if transportLayerType is 2 or 3
connId : Connection identifier, set it to “<ISM/SDA diameter stackId#neighbor hostId#connId>”.

chl.p: If SM has been deployed in Geographical Redundancy the DIA-CFG-NeighbourNode configuration has to be completed with the following information:

list-item.p: Add a new ipAddressList: <index 0>: SM zone 2 diameter stack IP address.
Create two times bigger number of connections than in SM towards ISM.
Add a new ipAddressList attribute with the following information:
<index1>:SM Zone 2 diameter stack IP address for half of the connections.
Add a new ipAddressList attribute with the following information:
<index1>:SM Zone 1 diameter stack IP address for the rest of the connections.
Create a DIA-CFG-NeighbourNode-LocalVIPNetRed object with the following information:
